author: By Shai Held
title: Passover’s Radical Message Is More Vital Than Ever
description: The Bible insists we turn our pain into understanding, love and empathy.
content: What do we do with our pain? What, if anything, can we learn from it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: The History of ‘Stereotype,’ Written on Metal Plates
description: Stereotype printing is pressed into the story of The New York Times.
content: The word “stereotype” first appeared in The New York Times in 1858. A young man, The Times reported, had been arrested “on a charge of stealing $300 worth of stereotype plates.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 21, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 21, 2024.
content: An article on Page 51 about projects that various artists are working on this year includes comments from the architect and designer Gaetano Pesce. Mr. Pesce died on April 3 at age 84.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 20, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 20, 2024.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the relocation of an ousted former leader from a prison in Myanmar to an unknown location misstated how long Myanmar’s military has controlled the country. It is more than half a century, not nearly half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Coming to Alabama: Newsom’s Abortion-Access Ad, Depicting an Arrest
description: The ad portrays a woman trying to leave the state to have an abortion. The Campaign for Democracy, a political action committee started by Mr. Newsom, the California governor, created it.
content: A woman nervously peers into her rearview mirror as a patrolman activates his car’s lights and sirens. She is less than a mile from leaving Alabama to seek abortion services, but it’s too late: The next thing she knows, she is being handed a pregnancy test and is handcuffed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas, Tariq Panja and Michael S. Schmidt
title: ‘Team USA Was Cheated’: Chinese Doping Case Exposes Rift in Swimming
description: An American who won silver in Tokyo calls for an investigation. A British gold medalist demands bans. But the most bitter fight was between antidoping leaders.
content: The revelation that 23 Chinese swimmers tested positive for a banned drug seven months before the Tokyo Olympics but were secretly cleared and allowed to continue competing has exposed a bitter and at times deeply personal rift inside the sport, and brought new criticism of the global authority that oversees drug-testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Pro-Israel Groups Promised to Be Active in Democratic Primaries. They Haven’t Done Much Yet.
description: The groups have raised millions to challenge candidates they see as not sufficiently pro-Israel, but have spent little as public opinion has shifted.
content: After Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel, pro-Israel political groups put the Democratic Party’s most outspoken critics of the Jewish state on notice: An avalanche of spending was coming to either unseat them or force them to change their posture on the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: How the Israel-Gaza Protests Could Hurt the Democratic Party
description: In 1968, the Democratic National Convention was overshadowed by clashes between police and demonstrators.
content: It’s a nightmare scenario for Democrats: Protesters disrupt their convention this summer; they clash with the police; chaos seems to take hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Crackdowns, Attacks and Threat of War Put Iranians on Edge
description: Facing deep economic troubles and a restive population, the government seems to have adopted a policy of declaring victory over Israel and cracking down at home, analysts say.
content: In the early hours of Friday, Mehrdad, an engineer in Isfahan, Iran, woke to the sound of explosions rattling the windows and shaking the ground. In Tehran, passengers about to board flights were abruptly told the airspace was closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Anne Lamott Has Written Classics. This Is Not One of Them.
description: Slim and precious, “Somehow: Thoughts on Love” doesn’t measure up to her best nonfiction.
content: Anne Lamott is a national treasure who, at age 70, is putting out not books but throw pillows with embroidered mottoes and little tassels. A lot of people find comfort in them and will curl right up with her latest, “Somehow,” a collection of inspirational anecdotes and meditations. Yours truly wants them off the bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 315
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Necessity Gives Rise to Bipartisanship — for Now
description: The far right finds itself marginalized in the House as Speaker Johnson pushes through aid to Ukraine and Israel by relying on Democrats.
content: When Congress convened in 2023, an empowered far-right Republican faction in the House threatened to upend Washington and President Biden’s agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Cities’ Efforts to Hold Police Accountable Hit a Wall: The Police
description: Civilian oversight boards face resistance across the country from those they are supposed to monitor. A New York case underscores the tension.
content: Last year, a woman in Albany, N.Y., filed a complaint with the civilian board responsible for investigating allegations of misconduct by the city’s police: She believed officers had not thoroughly investigated her claim that the father of her 3-year-old daughter had sexually assaulted the girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: Lots of Italy, on Many Collectible Plates
description: Buon Ricordo plates were introduced 60 years ago at restaurants in Italy. The hand-painted ceramics can now be found at design trade shows and fancy décor stores.
content: For his 73rd birthday in April, Felice Macchi had lunch at La Bettola Del Gusto, a restaurant in Pompeii, Italy, with a focus on seafood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Friend of Obama Who Could Soon Share the World Stage With Trump
description: After Britain’s next election, David Lammy is likely to be foreign secretary. He’s setting out a “progressive realist” policy — and forging ties on the U.S. right, just in case.
content: Few British politicians have American ties as deep as those of David Lammy, who is set to become Britain’s foreign secretary if the opposition Labour Party wins the coming election, as the polls suggest it will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Classic Chicken Dish That Makes You Feel Like a Grown-Up
description: Roasted chicken Provençal, with five stars and over 10,000 reviews, is effortlessly elegant.
content: Good morning. It’s been nearly a decade since the designer Steven Stolman taught me to make his chicken Provençal (above), and I’ve made it one gajillion times since (approximately). It’s a staple for dinner parties and Sunday suppers in my house — an excuse to iron napkins and use the plates we inherited from my wife’s grandmother, to finish the night with a glass of Sauternes and pretend I’m a grown-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Blackburn
title: We Regulate a Tiny Fraction of the 12,000 ‘Forever Chemicals.’ There’s a Better Way.
description: To reduce the risk PFAS post, we need far more comprehensive mandates that test, monitor and limit the entire class of chemicals.
content: When I was 12 years old, I sat inside a raucous tent revival in West Texas, gripping my seat in fear that a traveling evangelist would accuse me of killing my father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Schonbrun
title: Saturday Mornings With the ‘Voice of Problem Gambling’
description: Craig Carton, the bombastic sports broadcaster, shows a different side on a weekly show that focuses on the stories of gambling addicts like himself.
content: “Hello, my name is Craig Carton, with you for another 30 minutes for a frank, open conversation about gambling addiction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India to Redo Voting at Polling Stations Hit by Violence
description: The attacks occurred in Manipur, a northeastern state that has been troubled by ethnic unrest. Witnesses reported that voting booths were captured and bogus ballots cast.
content: India’s election authorities have directed officials to redo voting at several polling places in the troubled northeastern state of Manipur, after armed men attacked polling stations and captured voting booths despite the presence of dozens of paramilitary soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Vote to Resume U.S. Military Aid Is Met With Relief in Ukraine
description: Much-needed munitions like artillery shells could start arriving relatively quickly, but experts say it could take weeks before U.S. assistance has a direct impact on the war.
content: The Ukrainian lieutenant was at a firing position on the eastern front, commanding an artillery unit relying on American-provided M777 howitzers and other big guns, as U.S. lawmakers gathered in Washington to decide if his cannons would be forced to go silent for lack of ammunition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Spotted a Metal-and-Glass Shelving Unit in Perfect Condition’
description: “Stooping” in Manhattan, an unusual crack on a Broadway sidewalk and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Children Sing of Resistance at the Philharmonic
description: Olga Neuwirth’s “Keyframes for a Hippogriff,” a chaotic explosion of postmodernism, had its American premiere, conducted by Thomas Sondergard.
content: The composer Olga Neuwirth doesn’t tend to call her works anything as straightforward as symphonies or concertos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Isabel Kershner
title: Palestinians Go on Strike in West Bank to Protest Deadly Israeli Military Raid
description: At least 10 people were killed when Israeli forces raided the Nur Shams refugee camp, an episode that illustrated the territory’s continuing violence.
content: Palestinians in the West Bank on Sunday went on a general strike to protest an Israeli military raid at a refugee camp a day earlier in which at least 10 people were killed, in an episode that illustrated the continuing unrest in the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trita Parsi
title: Biden’s Small Win — and Bigger Failure — in the Middle East
description: President Biden’s win last week in the Middle East is part of a bigger failure.
content: President Biden’s behind-the-scenes crisis management appears to have helped stop a wider war from igniting in the Middle East — for now. But that tactical win for the administration is actually part of its much larger strategic failure in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Riley
title: Do Not Make Survival Even More Difficult for People on the Streets
description: A ban on camping in public places faces a Supreme Court test.
content: In 2013, Grants Pass, Ore., came up with a strategy to deal with a growing homeless population in the city of roughly 40,000, one that might best be described as kicking the can down the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Hell’s Kitchen’ Review: Alicia Keys’s Musical Finds Its Groove on Broadway
description: The retooled jukebox musical, with its top-notch performances and exciting choreography, “stands out as one of the rare must-sees” in a crowded season.
content: There was never much doubt that the Alicia Keys musical, “Hell’s Kitchen,” was going to be on Broadway. Keys spent 12 years developing a loosely autobiographical jukebox of her songs, incorporating such hits as “Girl on Fire,” “Fallin’” and “No One.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Jawbone in Child’s Rock Collection Linked to Marine Who Died in 1951
description: A mother found the bone in her son’s rock collection in 2002. In 2024, researchers finally identified the person’s remains.
content: A jawbone found in a child’s rock collection in Arizona more than two decades ago belonged to a Marine who died in California in 1951 and was buried in Missouri, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: Let Them Eat … Everything
description: In the age of Ozempic, the “fat activist” Virginia Sole-Smith is inspiring and infuriating her followers.
content: The sheet-pan chicken and roasted broccoli are out of the oven, and white rice is steaming on the stove. Virginia Sole-Smith, who has spent a decade writing about how women think and feel about their bodies — and how they pass along those feelings to their children through food — is about to serve dinner to her daughters, Violet, 10, and Beatrix, 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: How Mike Johnson Got to ‘Yes’ on Aid to Ukraine
description: Intelligence, politics and personal considerations converted the Republican speaker, who had largely opposed aid to Ukraine as a rank-and-file member, into the key figure pushing it through Congress.
content: For weeks after the Senate passed a sprawling aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, Speaker Mike Johnson agonized over whether and how the House would take up funding legislation that would almost certainly infuriate the right wing of his party and could cost him his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annemarie Conte
title: E-Commerce and the Influencer Economy
description: How internet shopping became choked with junk.
content: People are bombarded online each day with ads for newfangled products that promise dramatic life improvements. Modish tumblers. Sleek pans. Miraculous cleaning solutions. Overblown air purifiers. Just click this link and — voilà! Productivity. Happiness. Nirvana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Welcome to Scam World
description: To own a computer or smartphone — indeed, to engage with the digital world to any degree — is to be a mark. You can try to block, encrypt and unsubscribe your way out of it, but you may not succeed.
content: You open your eyes and grope for your phone. You check your inbox and discover dozens of spam emails that made it past the filter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Line Between Good and Evil Cuts Through Evangelical America
description: Evangelicals, fundamentalists and Pentecostals are taking the church in very different directions.
content: I’m afraid that an exit poll question has confused America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Dismissed Trump Jurors Describe Intense Days in a Glaring Spotlight
description: Two prospective jurors who were excused contacted The New York Times to describe their experience in the fraught environment of an unprecedented trial.
content: The two Manhattan residents were led into the courtroom to fulfill a foundational civic duty: to be interviewed as prospective jurors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Terry Anderson, Reporter Held Hostage for Six Years, Dies at 76
description: The Beirut bureau chief for The Associated Press, he was kidnapped in 1985 by Islamic militants.
content: Terry Anderson, the American journalist who had been the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon when he was finally released in 1991 by Islamic militants after more than six years in captivity, died on Saturday at his home in Greenwood Lake, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: U.S. Poised to Resume Aid to Ukraine
description: Also, Iran appears to stand down after Israel’s strike and Myanmar’s conflict may be shifting.
content: The House voted on Saturday in favor of $95 billion in long-stalled foreign aid for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, resoundingly approving the funds over months of objections from Republicans on the far right. The Senate is expected to pass the legislation as early as tomorrow, and it is almost certain to become law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Ferris
title: How Did Fan Culture Take Over? And Why Is It So Scary?
description: Justin Taylor’s novel “Reboot” examines the convergence of entertainment, online arcana and conspiracy theory.
content: There are two kinds of novels about American life in the digital age: panoramas and selfies. The former are surveys of a wired world’s structures and networks, like Dave Eggers’s fictionalization of Big Tech in “The Circle” and Jennifer Egan’s interconnected New York in “The Candy House.” The latter, like Patricia Lockwood’s “No One Is Talking About This” and Lauren Oyler’s “Fake Accounts,” are intimate portraits of the experience of being very online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 22, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Slows Campaign Spending as He Tries to Close Cash Gap With Biden
description: President Biden’s campaign had $85.5 million on hand at the end of March, filings show, and Donald Trump had $45 million, but the president is spending far more freely on the race.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign committee ended March with $45 million on hand, federal filings showed Saturday, as he tries to close the fund-raising gap with President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: In a Country Awash in Violence, a Vote Will Test Its Leader’s Hard-Line Stance
description: Less than six months after Daniel Noboa became the president of Ecuador, voters will decide on a referendum that could gauge how he would do in his bid for re-election next year.
content: Ecuadoreans will vote on Sunday in a referendum that could give their center-right president greater powers to combat drug-related gang violence and also gauge how he would fare in his bid for re-election next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Nicole Tung
title: Russian Attacks Crush Factories and Way of Life in Ukrainian Villages
description: The assaults have all but destroyed the factories and plants that were the economic lifeblood of the towns and cities in Ukraine’s east.
content: Its towering smokestacks once puffed out clouds of steam. In gigantic machine rooms, turbines whirled around the clock. Furnaces burned trainloads of coal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Will a Mountain of Evidence Be Enough to Convict Trump?
description: Monday will see opening statements in the People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump. The state’s case seems strong, but a conviction is far from assured.
content: In the official record, the case is known as the People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump, and, for now, the people have the stronger hand: They have insider witnesses, a favorable jury pool and a lurid set of facts about a presidential candidate, a payoff and a porn star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: What to Know About State Laws That Limit or Ban D.E.I. Efforts at Colleges
description: Diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives have become a target of conservatives across the nation, with several states passing laws against them.
content: In recent decades, American universities have expanded their diversity programs to address concerns about the underrepresentation of minority groups on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The TV Show That Predicted America’s Lonely, Disorienting Digital Future
description: For 12 years, the MTV reality series “Catfish” has traveled the U.S., presenting hundreds of intimate snapshots of what can go wrong when the heart mixes with technology.
content: Since its first episode aired in 2012, “Catfish: The TV Show” has held up a mirror to our online lives, reflecting how we present ourselves and make sense of love, lust, trust, companionship and loneliness in an increasingly digital world. Each episode unfolds like a detective show, with the host Nev Schulman summoned to untangle truth from lies, to take relationships that exist only on computers and phones and drag them into our three-dimensional reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zixu Wang and Yan Zhuang
title: Heavy Rains Hit Southern China as Hong Kong Spots a Waterspout
description: Bad weather in Guangdong Province forced evacuations as forecasters warned of more rain and potential flooding.
content: Torrential rain battered southern China on Sunday, causing flooding and forcing tens of thousands of evacuations in the country’s most populous province, as a waterspout appeared briefly in Hong Kong and forecasters warned of potentially severe flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Driver Plows Into Michigan Birthday Party, Killing 2 Children
description: An 8-year-old girl and her 5-year-old brother were killed, and 15 others were injured, when the driver drove through a wall at a boat club, the police said.
content: A drunken driver plowed into a building where a children’s birthday party was being held in Michigan on Saturday afternoon, killing two young siblings and injuring at least 15 other people, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Barking Orders
description: David Kahn makes progress step by step.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: New York Has a $237 Billion Budget. Here Are 5 Things to Know.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul and New York City emerged as two of the winners from a budget process that blew past the April 1 deadline.
content: In the three weeks since the April 1 deadline for a state budget passed, New York lawmakers experienced an eclipse, an earthquake and a cyberattack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Tania Ganguli
title: In Latest Gambling Scandal, Some See Glimpse of Sports’ Future
description: The N.B.A. banned a player for life for betting on games, a practice some worry could become more prevalent with the rise of wagering on sports.
content: Bill Bradley, the basketball Hall of Famer and former United States senator known as a staunch opponent of legalized sports betting, was speaking about the topic back in January. But he might as well have been predicting the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Climate Doom Is Out. ‘Apocalyptic Optimism’ Is In.
description: Focusing on disaster hasn’t changed the planet’s trajectory. Will a more upbeat approach show a way forward?
content: The philanthropist Kathryn Murdoch has prioritized donations to environmental causes for more than a decade. She has, she said, a deep understanding of how inhospitable the planet will become if climate change is not addressed. And she and her colleagues have spent years trying to communicate that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Adam Rasgon and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Considers Imposing Sanctions on Israeli Military Unit
description: Israeli leaders expressed alarm about the possible action by the Biden administration over rights violations in the West Bank.
content: The United States is considering imposing sanctions on one or more Israeli battalions accused of human rights violations during operations in the occupied West Bank, according to a person familiar with the deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: How the Movie ‘Civil War’ Echoes Real Political Anxieties
description: “Civil War” has tapped into a dark set of national angst. In polls and in interviews, a segment of voters say they fear the country’s divides may lead to actual, not just rhetorical, battles.
content: One subject seems to be unifying the right and the left today: Disunion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: Tracing the Trail of Hush-Money Deals That Led to Trump’s Prosecution
description: Before Stormy Daniels, Donald J. Trump and his allies paid to keep other stories buried as he ran for the presidency.
content: Donald J. Trump and two confidants hatched a plan in August 2015 to boost his upstart presidential campaign, prosecutors say. They carried it out, and Mr. Trump won the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Trial Challenge: Being Stripped of Control
description: The mundanity of the courtroom has all but swallowed Donald Trump, who for decades has sought to project an image of bigness and a sense of power.
content: “Sir, can you please have a seat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: Give Me Liberty or Give Me … What?
description: Alex Garland’s “Civil War” is not a vision of what might happen in America but a collage of what already has happened, some here and much elsewhere.
content: If the American experiment finally decides to call it quits, how might a national breakup begin?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Golden Visa Programs, Once a Boon, Lose Their Luster
description: Spain is the latest European country to end its program, which brought in billions of euros from real estate investors seeking residency status but worsened a housing crisis for locals.
content: When Ana Jimena Barba, a young doctor, began working at a hospital in Madrid last year, she moved in with her parents half an hour outside the city until she could save enough to buy her own home. But when she started looking at houses in the same village, almost everything was priced at more than 500,000 euros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Rally, a Return to the Campaign Trail, Is Called Off Because of Storms
description: After a week stuck in a courtroom, Donald Trump was planning to speak to thousands of supporters in North Carolina, until the weather turned dangerous.
content: After former President Donald J. Trump sat in a courtroom in New York for much of the last week, Saturday night was supposed to herald a return to the campaign trail and the large rallies where he often gives long, freewheeling speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ragtag Resistance Sees the Tide Turning
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 21, 2024.
content: “Looking for the help of the U.N., looking for the help of the international governments, is like walking in the dark. We have to do by ourself to escape from this kind of hell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike and Ruth Fremson
title: A Utah Mountain Town Brings Back an Old Idea: The One-Room Schoolhouse
description: As a throwback ski destination, Alta thinks small, with a one-room public school to match.
content: As long as it has had a ski resort, Alta, Utah, has been a place where young people come to work for a season before starting life in the real world, then end up staying for two or 10 or 20 years — even a lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das, Joe Ward and Matthew Cullen
title: China’s Swimmers Tested Positive. What Happens to Their Medals?
description: The short answer may be nothing. The world’s top doping regulator said there was “no credible evidence” to take further action.
content: Whenever a suspicion of doping arises in an Olympics, attention can shift quickly from the athletes who won gold, silver and bronze medals to the ones who missed out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Waxman and Adam Klein
title: Government Surveillance Keeps Us Safe
description: A surveillance law referred to as Section 702 is needed to protect us from foreign threats.
content: This is an extraordinarily dangerous time for the United States and our allies. Israel’s unpreparedness on Oct. 7 shows that even powerful nations can be surprised in catastrophic ways. Fortunately, Congress, in a rare bipartisan act, voted early Saturday to reauthorize a key intelligence power that provides critical information on hostile states and threats ranging from terrorism to fentanyl trafficking.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Alcohol Labels Warn of Cancer Risks?
description: Readers discuss whether the U.S. should follow the lead of Ireland and other countries. Also: Travel-related illnesses; affordable housing for immigrants.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek, Gabriel Blanco and Claire Hogan
title: What to Watch as Donald Trump’s Hush-Money Trial Begins
description: A jury has been selected and opening arguments are set to begin in Donald Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan. Kate Christobek, a court reporter for The New York Times, breaks down what to watch.
content: A jury has been selected and opening arguments are set to begin in Donald Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan. Kate Christobek, a court reporter for The New York Times, breaks down what to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘History Will Judge It Well,’ Speaker Johnson Says of Aid to Ukraine
description: Speaker Mike Johnson successfully defied the anti-interventionalist wing of the Republican Party and got the House to approve a $95 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson successfully defied the anti-interventionalist wing of the Republican Party and got the House to approve a $95 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times
